addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

17 Au
g
1595.
M
r
Bodley to my L. From
e Haghe.
W
th
a Copie of his Proposic
o
n to
The'stat
.
Rec at
Nonesuch
the xxvj
th
of
e same.

page.lettertext:
fol.95r
14 Au
g
1595 M
r
Bodeleys letter to my L.
May it please yo
r
good L. I had my audience
w
t
e states,
e 14 of this p
nt
: where I presented
unto them her
Ma
ties
l
re
s, and added so muche
14 Au
g
more, as I had ether in charge, by vertue of my
Instructions, or was otherwise enjoined from her
Ma
tie
by worde: wherupon they required to have
my speeches in writing, w
ch
I exhibited
e next
day after, and send heere inclosed
e copie to yo
r
L. Other answear I had none, more then
commonly they give, at
e first proposal of a
mater, That they would take advise up
o
it:
w
ch
yet they uttered unto me w
t
signification of
their grief,
at her Hig
es
would proceede so di-
rectly against her Treatie, and
at in suche a
season, as if their state were thoroughly sifted,
it would be founde in greater danger, then it was
at
e time of
e making of
e Contract.
They have mette very often about
e mater, and
yester afternoone, because I pressed them hard, to
knowe to w
at
effect I should write unto her Ma
tie
they deputed one to tell me, that I must needes
have
e patience, to attend a litle longer: for
at
they had not yet c
o
cluded, w
at
answear they
might make, but founde it every way a mater
full of infinit danger, if they should not proceede
w
t
very great circumspection: for w
ch
they were
agreed, to impart it out of hand to
Co. Maurice
and
Co. William
, and to
e
Councel of Estate
, w
ch
are together at
e Campe, to
e end, w
t
their ad-
vise, they might determine for
e best.
fol.95v
As farre as I can conjecture, they are all fully
bent to satisfie her Ma
tie
in sending to
e
Provinces,
but I can not yet perceave, in w
at
sort they are in-
clined, to propose
e mater to
e Provinces. For
if they doe it effectually, by imparting their ad-
vise, and by persuading w
t
e people, to assent
to a certaine summe, ether
at w
ch
I have signified,
or
at they shall sette downe, I may happely have
an answear w
t
some expedition. But if they
will not determine, to give direction to
e Provin-
ces (as I finde them
at way very backward)
but shall barely make req
e
st, to knowe their reso-
lution up
o
her Ma
ties
l
re
s, and my propositions, suche
a general kinde of writing will occasion great va-
rietie in returne of their answears, w
ch
are of
force to be reduced, by often sending too and fro, to
a full accorde of all in one (because they goe not
in suche cases by pluralitie of voices) and then
what time it will require, yo
r
L. will con-
jecture. I will therfore endevo
r
, by all
e meanes
I can devise, to drawe them heere before hand, to
agree upon a portion worth her Hi
ges
acceptation,
and to move
e generallitie to condescend therunto.
I have publickly proposed, as her Ma
tie
willed,
a
hundred thousand poundes
, but they shewe so
litle token of hearkning unto it, as I must growe
to other termes in my privat communication, or
els expect to be denied. For to informe yo
w
roundly w
at
I finde, w
t
humble suite unto yo
r
L.
to make it knowen unto her Ma
tie
I see
e chiefest
heere among them full of silence and sadnesse, for
fol.96r
e troubles and discomfortes, w
ch
they declare to come
by heapes upon
e people of this contrey, and to
minister muche mater of discouragem
t
and danger.
They alleage in dealing w
t
me, their losses in winter,
by
e great inundations, wherof a great contrey com-
plaineth continually;
e contention of
e Provinces,
about their contributions, w
ch
are not yet appeared;
the consumption of their troupes, w
ch
they sent to
e
D. of Bouillon
;
e foiles they had at
Huy,
and
at divers times sins, in smalle encounters w
t
e Ene-
mie;
e dangerous conseqence of
e overthrowes in
France;
their ill successe at
Grolle,
and
e g
nr
al
puissance of
e Enemie both heere, and in France,
having p
nt
ly a foote fower several armies, in
Bri-
tanie
,
Burgundie,
Cambresie
and heere. To this
they adde
e soddaine want,
at is noted of all men,
of Zele in religion, in
e people of this contrey;
their excessive dommages sustained by
e staies
made of late of their shipping in
Spaine;
e spoiles
that have bin done up
o
their marchants shippes by
Dunkerkers, who are saied w
t
in these 2 monethes
to have taken at
e lest a 100 shippes of this c
o
trey,
and not so a litle as
e value of a 150000
li
ster
l
.
They also put unto
e reckning
e continual detri-
ment, w
ch
they receave by Englishe sea men; and
e
smalle assurance
at they have, to hold her Ma
ties
forces, ether those
at her Hig
es
or
e contrey intertaineth,
but are most of all moved w
t
this message of mine
for restitution of her monies: in so muche as they
affirme,
at if there come not in somwhat some amendement
fol.96v
of their state, to keepe
e people from despaire (wherof
they doe protest,
at their hope is very slender) they
are very muche in doubt of some soddaine alteration:
w
ch
is also feared will beginne among
e mariner
and sea men:
at as they were
e chiefest in deli-
vering
e contrey from
e bondage of
e Enemie, so
they doubt
at nowe againe they will be readiest to
revolt, if their trafficque be impeached, w
ch
e
spaniard, out of qestion, will omitte no practise to
effect. And very nowe heere is newes from S
t
Lucar
in Spaine,
at
e K. hath prohibited by publicke Edict,
the paiment of any debt to any person of these Pro-
vinces, w
ch
is supposed will extend to
e undoing
heere of many. There was a l
re
intercepted
about this time twelve moneth, written by one
Fri-
derj Spinder
(as it seemeth a seaman) to
Yvarra,
at
Bruxelles;
by whome a q
e
stion had bin moved
about
e use of galleys up
o
e coast of
Flanders,
for cutting of
e trafficque of
Holland
and
Zeland,
because I am not certaine,
at yo
r
L. hath seene it,
and we heare
at
e Enemie is busie againe about
it, I have sent yo
w
a transcript of it. It was
written in ciphers, and deciphred by
Mons
r
S
t
Al-
degonde
. Upon
e siege of
Cambray
by
e
Co. de Fuentes,
there goeth already a great feare
among some,
at it will be caried er be long. For
Mons
r
Balignj
, they say, is very ill beloved both of
e bourghers and souldiers, who are doubted to be no
more then seven or eight hundred, wheras
e towne
doth require 3000 at
e lest, to make good resist
a
ce,
fol.97r
w
t
a great deale greater stoare of warlicke pro-
vision, then is there to be founde, by all report.
It is also comonly spoken,
at if
La Motte
had lived
de Fuentes first intention was to goe in hand w
t
Calais:
in so muche as those of Zeland up
o
reqest of
e governo
r
, were determined to send thither 6 or 7
companies, having sent already up
o
e bruite a cer-
tain
tie
quantitie of powder. There is a general
conceat among
e wisest of these contreis, considering
howe de Fuentes is both governo
r
by provision, and
Financier, whereby he hath autoritie to undertake
what he list, and
e meanes in his handes to per-
fourme his designes, w
ch
was nether graunted to
Er-
nestus
, nor to
e
D. of Parma
: considering also his
sufficiencie, for
e managing of his buisnesse, and
his victories of late, in
e most of his attemptes:
and
at
e
King
hath no occasion, to be so jalouse
of his doinges, as it seemed he was ever of
e D. of
Parma before:
at
e comming of
e Cardinal will
be staied for all together, and an absolut comission
c
o
ferred on
e Count. Co. Maurice w
t
his Campe is said to be about
Bislike
a place adjoi-
ning unto
Wesel
in
e land of
Cleve,
and
e Enemie
neere unto him, w
t
in two houres marche: but heere
is nothing reported of any thing lately done, of one
side or other. The states are very willing,
at
e
Co. should returne, and put his people in garrison,
for
at they finde it a heavy charge, to continue him
there: but doubting lest
e Enemie, who is saied
to be strong 5000 foote and 1500 horse, should repaire
to de Fuentes at
e siege of Cambray, they stand
fol.97v
doubtfull w
at
to doe. Having seene certaine
copies of intercepted l
re
s, w
ch
M
r
Gilpin
of late
hath sent unto yo
r
L. by a clause in a l
re
of
W[illiam]
Creichton
, That a certaine Englishe man shoul[d be]
taken in
e Northpartes of
England,
w
t
one
David
Lawe
a Scottishe priest, I calle to minde w
at
was writ-
ten to
Tyrius
at
Rome,
by
e self same Creichton i[n]
a former l
re
intercepted, w
ch
I sent unto yo
r
L. at
my last being heere, to witte,
at he had sent a man
w
t
David Lawe, who had undertaken to effect by
way of persuasion, some special mater in 429. w
ch
I ghesse to be Scotia, as me thinkes it is also mani-
fest
at 428 is Anglus, and 427 Anglia, and
perhaps some man els could aime at
e rest, contai-
ning somw
at
, in my opini
o
, of very good mome[nt].
W
ch
may perhaps be discovered by
e examinati
o
of Williamson, who I learne was
e man
at was
taken w
t
Lawe, and is meant as I thinke, in
e l
re
of Creichton. Though yo
r
L. may have noted
this mater before, yet I thought it not impertin
e
t
to remember yo
w
of it, and to send yo
w
e copie
of
at part of
e l
re
, w
ch
toucheth
at mater.
I sawe a l
re
right nowe from
Morlaix
in Britaine,
that all a long
e cost between
at and
Brest,
e Spaniard is busied in making of fortes, so as if
he may be suffered for two monethes together, it will
be found very hard to chase him away. Though yo
r
L.
wantes no meanes, to knowe those occurrences, yet
e l
re
being freshe, and comming so fitly, at
e writing
hereof. I thought to touche it in a worde. Heere is
also notice at this instant,
at
e mutined Italians
are like to come to c
o
position: w
ch
will adde a
great strength to
e Enemies forces.
And thus
I take my humble leave. Fr
o
e Hage. 17 Au
g
95.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
